subhead: A community leader and a resident told The Associated Press that about 100 militants participated in the attack in Dargo (North), burning and looting the base after the killings. The Jama’at Nasr al-Islam wal-Muslimin group is suspected of having carried out the attack.

title: Tariffs: The EU's 'lost opportunity'
subhead: Although trade is one of the European Union's main areas of competence, the EU refused to enter into a trade conflict with President Donald Trump, risking its long-term credibility. France's voice was barely heard.

title: Economist Dmitry Nekrasov: 'Only a handful of sanctions have had a serious effect on Putin's ability to continue the war'
subhead: Nekrasov, a former Kremlin adviser who joined the opposition and now lives in exile, discusses the EU's latest package of sanctions against Russia and their potential effectiveness.

title: 'In the West Berlin squats, we argued but lived together': Karin Wieland, political rebel
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (2/6). In the late 1970s, Karin Wieland fled her small German town to live communally in an abandoned building in Kreuzberg, throwing herself into every cause of the era.

title: 'Half the city lay in ruins': Hanns Zischler, the cultural memory of West Berlin
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (1/6). The actor, writer, translator, and photographer, a figure of Germany's artistic and intellectual scene, arrived in the walled-in city in the early 1970s. He never left, drawn by a vibrancy that set West Berlin apart from the rest of the Federal Republic of Germany at the time.

title: Letters from prisoners held in solitary confinement: 'I feel like becoming violent again'
subhead: Le Monde asked five prisoners and a former inmate – the armed robber Rédoine Faïd, four drug traffickers, and a radicalized Islamist – to recount daily life in solitary confinement.
byline: By Grégoire Biseau, Thomas Saintourens and Lucie Soullier

title: Nika Lozovska, chef: 'I work in a London restaurant called Brat. In Ukrainian, that means brother'
subhead: 'Refugee Recipes' (2/6). After training in Paris, Chef Nika Lozovska opened her restaurant, Dizyngoff, in the Black Sea city of Odesa in 2015. She fled the war in Ukraine and settled in London, where she keeps the memory of her hometown alive through a heirloom tomato and samphire salad.
